title: Roy Bentley
text:
Roy Thomas Frank Bentley (17 May 1924 – 20 April 2018) was an English <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager.
A former <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>, Bentley played 367 games for <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> and captained the club to their first <a href="List%20of%20English%20football%20champions">League Championship</a> in the <a href="1954%E2%80%9355%20in%20English%20football">1954–55 season</a>. He also won 12 <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">caps</a> for the <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England national side</a>.
Personal life.
Bentley was born in <a href="Shirehampton">Shirehampton</a>, Bristol, Gloucestershire and attended Portway Boys Secondary School.
He married Violet M. Upton in 1946.
Club career.
Early years.
Bentley served in the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> during the Second World War and afterwards played for both <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a> and <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a> before signing for <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> in 1946. He was with the club for less than two years, but formed a key part of a forward line which also included <a href="Jackie%20Milburn">Jackie Milburn</a>, <a href="Len%20Shackleton">Len Shackleton</a> and <a href="Charlie%20Wayman">Charlie Wayman</a>. He reached an <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> semi-final with the club in the <a href="1946%E2%80%9347%20in%20English%20football">1946–47</a> season, but they were defeated 4–0 by eventual winners <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a>.
Chelsea.
In January 1948 Bentley signed for London side Chelsea for £11,000, He captained Chelsea to their first <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">League</a> title, in <a href="1954%E2%80%9355%20in%20English%20football">1954–55</a>.
Having scored 150 goals in 367 appearances, Bentley was Chelsea's top goalscorer and, at the time of his death in 2018, was fifth in Chelsea's <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.%20statistics%23Goalscorers">all-time goalscorers</a> list behind <a href="Bobby%20Tambling">Bobby Tambling</a>, <a href="Frank%20Lampard">Frank Lampard</a>, <a href="Kerry%20Dixon">Kerry Dixon</a> and <a href="Didier%20Drogba">Didier Drogba</a>.
International career.
Bentley was an <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> international for six years, playing at the <a href="1950%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1950 FIFA World Cup</a>.
Management.
Following his retirement from playing, Bentley moved into management. He took over at <a href="Reading%20F.C.">Reading</a> and later <a href="Swansea%20City%20A.F.C.">Swansea City</a>, winning promotion to the old <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> with the latter. He returned to Reading in 1977, this time as club secretary.
Retirement and death.
Bentley lived in <a href="Chigwell">Chigwell</a>, <a href="Essex">Essex</a> during the late 1980s before relocating to <a href="Reading%2C%20Berkshire">Reading, Berkshire</a> where he lived in 2014. At his death in April 2018, he was the last surviving player from England's <a href="1950%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1950 World Cup</a> squad.
